simulation.orchestrators.parallelÂ¶

Source: src\simulation\orchestrators\parallel.py

Module OverviewÂ¶

Parallel simulation orchestrator for multi-threaded execution.

Mathematical FoundationÂ¶

Parallel Simulation OrchestrationÂ¶

Multi-threaded execution for independent simulation runs.

Parallel Computing ModelÂ¶

Embarrassingly parallel problem:

\[\text{Results} = \bigcup_{i=1}^{M} \text{Simulate}(x_0^{(i)}, \text{config}^{(i)})\]

Each simulation is independent (no inter-simulation communication).

Amdahlâ€™s LawÂ¶

Theoretical speedup limit:

\[S(N) = \frac{1}{(1-P) + \frac{P}{N}}\]

Where:

  • \(S(N)\): Speedup with \(N\) processors

  • \(P\): Parallelizable fraction of work

  • \((1-P)\): Serial fraction

For Monte Carlo simulations: \(P \approx 1\) (near-perfect parallelization)

Maximum speedup:

\[\lim_{N \to \infty} S(N) = \frac{1}{1-P}\]

For \(P=0.99\): \(S_{\max} = 100\)

Gustafsonâ€™s Law (Scaled Speedup)Â¶

More realistic model for growing problem sizes:

\[S(N) = (1-P) + N \cdot P\]

Linear speedup for \(P \approx 1\)

Thread Pool ArchitectureÂ¶

Work queue pattern:

\[\begin{split}\begin{align} \text{Tasks} &= \{\text{Sim}_1, \text{Sim}_2, \ldots, \text{Sim}_M\} \\ \text{Workers} &= \{W_1, W_2, \ldots, W_N\} \\ \text{Queue} &: \text{Tasks} \to \text{Workers} \end{align}\end{split}\]

Load balancing: Dynamic task assignment ensures even workload distribution

Parallel EfficiencyÂ¶

Efficiency metric:

\[E(N) = \frac{S(N)}{N} = \frac{T_1}{N \cdot T_N}\]

Where:

  • \(T_1\): Sequential execution time

  • \(T_N\): Parallel execution time with \(N\) cores

Target: \(E(N) > 0.8\) (80% efficiency)

Synchronization OverheadÂ¶

Total execution time:

\[T_{\text{parallel}} = T_{\text{compute}} + T_{\text{sync}} + T_{\text{overhead}}\]

Overhead components:

  • Thread creation/destruction

  • Task queue management

  • Result aggregation

  • Memory allocation/deallocation

Typical overhead: 5-10% for Monte Carlo simulations

Python GIL ConsiderationÂ¶

Global Interpreter Lock (GIL):

  • Python threads share one GIL

  • CPU-bound code: Limited by GIL (no true parallelism)

  • I/O-bound code: GIL released during I/O (true parallelism)

Solution for DIP simulations:

  • Use multiprocessing instead of threading

  • Numba @njit functions release GIL

  • C-extension integration libraries release GIL

Speedup AnalysisÂ¶

Expected speedup for M simulations on N cores:

\[T_{\text{parallel}} = \frac{M}{N} \cdot T_{\text{sim}} + T_{\text{overhead}}\]

Ideal speedup:

\[S = \frac{M \cdot T_{\text{sim}}}{\frac{M}{N} \cdot T_{\text{sim}}} = N\]

Actual speedup (with overhead):

\[S_{\text{actual}} = \frac{M \cdot T_{\text{sim}}}{\frac{M}{N} \cdot T_{\text{sim}} + T_{\text{overhead}}}\]

Performance BenchmarksÂ¶

Memory ScalingÂ¶

Memory per worker:

\[M_{\text{worker}} = M_{\text{state}} + M_{\text{controller}} + M_{\text{integrator}}\]

Total memory:

\[M_{\text{total}} = N \cdot M_{\text{worker}} + M_{\text{shared}}\]

Architecture DiagramÂ¶

graph TB A[Task Queue] --> B{Distribute} B --> C[Worker 1] B --> D[Worker 2] B --> E[Worker 3] B --> F[Worker N] C --> G[Simulate 1] D --> H[Simulate 2] E --> I[Simulate 3] F --> J[Simulate M] G --> K[Collect Results] H --> K I --> K J --> K K --> L[Aggregate] style A fill:#9cf style K fill:#ff9 style L fill:#9f9

Usage ExamplesÂ¶

Example 1: Basic UsageÂ¶

from src.simulation.orchestrators import OrchestratorsParallel

# Initialize
instance = OrchestratorsParallel()

# Execute
result = instance.process(data)

Example 2: Advanced ConfigurationÂ¶

# Custom configuration
config = {'parameter': 'value'}
instance = OrchestratorsParallel(config)
result = instance.process(data)

Example 3: Error HandlingÂ¶

try:
    result = instance.process(data)
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

Example 4: Performance ProfilingÂ¶

import time
start = time.time()
result = instance.process(data)
elapsed = time.time() - start
print(f"Execution time: {elapsed:.4f} s")

Example 5: Integration with Other ComponentsÂ¶

# Combine with other simulation components
result = orchestrator.execute(instance.process(data))

Complete Source CodeÂ¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#====================== src/simulation/orchestrators/parallel.py ======================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""Parallel simulation orchestrator for multi-threaded execution."""
  6
  7from __future__ import annotations
  8
  9import time
 10from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed
 11from typing import Any, Callable, List, Optional
 12import numpy as np
 13
 14from .base import BaseOrchestrator
 15from .sequential import SequentialOrchestrator
 16from ..core.interfaces import ResultContainer
 17from ..results.containers import BatchResultContainer
 18
 19
 20class ParallelOrchestrator(BaseOrchestrator):
 21    """Parallel simulation orchestrator for multi-threaded execution.
 22
 23    This orchestrator executes multiple simulations in parallel using
 24    a thread pool, providing performance improvements for independent
 25    simulation runs such as Monte Carlo analysis.
 26    """
 27
 28    def __init__(self, context, max_workers: Optional[int] = None):
 29        """Initialize parallel orchestrator.
 30
 31        Parameters
 32        ----------
 33        context : SimulationContext
 34            Simulation context
 35        max_workers : int, optional
 36            Maximum number of worker threads (default: CPU count)
 37        """
 38        super().__init__(context)
 39        self.max_workers = max_workers
 40
 41    def execute(self,
 42               initial_state: np.ndarray,
 43               control_inputs: np.ndarray,
 44               dt: float,
 45               horizon: int,
 46               **kwargs) -> ResultContainer:
 47        """Execute parallel simulation.
 48
 49        Parameters
 50        ----------
 51        initial_state : np.ndarray
 52            Initial state(s) - shape (state_dim,) or (batch_size, state_dim)
 53        control_inputs : np.ndarray
 54            Control input sequence(s)
 55        dt : float
 56            Time step
 57        horizon : int
 58            Simulation horizon
 59        **kwargs
 60            Additional options
 61
 62        Returns
 63        -------
 64        ResultContainer
 65            Parallel simulation results
 66        """
 67        self._validate_simulation_inputs(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon)
 68
 69        start_time = time.perf_counter()
 70
 71        # Determine if this is a batch of simulations
 72        initial_state = np.atleast_2d(initial_state)
 73        batch_size = initial_state.shape[0]
 74
 75        if batch_size == 1:
 76            # Single simulation - use sequential orchestrator
 77            sequential = SequentialOrchestrator(self.context)
 78            result = sequential.execute(initial_state[0], control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)
 79        else:
 80            # Multiple simulations - execute in parallel
 81            result = self._execute_parallel_batch(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)
 82
 83        # Update statistics
 84        execution_time = time.perf_counter() - start_time
 85        total_steps = batch_size * horizon
 86        self._update_stats(total_steps, execution_time)
 87
 88        return result
 89
 90    def _execute_parallel_batch(self,
 91                               initial_states: np.ndarray,
 92                               control_inputs: np.ndarray,
 93                               dt: float,
 94                               horizon: int,
 95                               **kwargs) -> ResultContainer:
 96        """Execute batch simulations in parallel."""
 97        batch_size = initial_states.shape[0]
 98
 99        # Prepare individual simulation parameters
100        simulation_params = []
101        for i in range(batch_size):
102            initial_state = initial_states[i]
103
104            # Extract control inputs for this simulation
105            if control_inputs.ndim == 1:
106                # Single control sequence for all
107                controls = control_inputs
108            elif control_inputs.ndim == 2:
109                if control_inputs.shape[0] == batch_size:
110                    # Batch of control sequences
111                    controls = control_inputs[i]
112                else:
113                    # Single control sequence with multiple inputs per step
114                    controls = control_inputs
115            elif control_inputs.ndim == 3:
116                # Batch of multi-input control sequences
117                controls = control_inputs[i]
118            else:
119                controls = control_inputs
120
121            simulation_params.append((initial_state, controls, dt, horizon, kwargs.copy()))
122
123        # Execute simulations in parallel
124        results = []
125        with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=self.max_workers) as executor:
126            # Submit all simulations
127            future_to_index = {
128                executor.submit(self._run_single_simulation, *params): i
129                for i, params in enumerate(simulation_params)
130            }
131
132            # Collect results as they complete
133            for future in as_completed(future_to_index):
134                index = future_to_index[future]
135                try:
136                    result = future.result()
137                    results.append((index, result))
138                except Exception as e:
139                    # Handle failed simulation
140                    print(f"Simulation {index} failed: {e}")
141                    results.append((index, None))
142
143        # Sort results by original index
144        results.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
145
146        # Combine into batch result container
147        batch_result = BatchResultContainer()
148        for index, result in results:
149            if result is not None:
150                states = result.get_states()
151                times = result.get_times()
152                controls = getattr(result, 'controls', None)
153
154                batch_result.add_trajectory(states, times,
155                                          controls=controls, batch_index=index)
156
157        return batch_result
158
159    def _run_single_simulation(self,
160                             initial_state: np.ndarray,
161                             control_inputs: np.ndarray,
162                             dt: float,
163                             horizon: int,
164                             kwargs: dict) -> ResultContainer:
165        """Run a single simulation using sequential orchestrator.
166
167        This method creates a new sequential orchestrator for each worker
168        to avoid thread safety issues.
169        """
170        # Create a new context for this thread
171        context = type(self.context)(self.context.config.model_dump_json())
172        sequential = SequentialOrchestrator(context)
173
174        return sequential.execute(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)
175
176
177class WorkerPool:
178    """Reusable worker pool for parallel simulations."""
179
180    def __init__(self, max_workers: Optional[int] = None):
181        """Initialize worker pool.
182
183        Parameters
184        ----------
185        max_workers : int, optional
186            Maximum number of worker threads
187        """
188        self.max_workers = max_workers
189        self.executor = None
190
191    def __enter__(self):
192        """Enter context manager."""
193        self.executor = ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=self.max_workers)
194        return self
195
196    def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb):
197        """Exit context manager."""
198        if self.executor:
199            self.executor.shutdown(wait=True)
200
201    def map_simulations(self,
202                       simulation_fn: Callable,
203                       parameters: List[Any]) -> List[Any]:
204        """Map simulation function over parameter list.
205
206        Parameters
207        ----------
208        simulation_fn : callable
209            Simulation function to execute
210        parameters : list
211            List of parameter tuples for each simulation
212
213        Returns
214        -------
215        list
216            List of simulation results
217        """
218        if self.executor is None:
219            raise RuntimeError("Worker pool not initialized. Use as context manager.")
220
221        futures = [self.executor.submit(simulation_fn, *params) for params in parameters]
222        results = []
223
224        for future in as_completed(futures):
225            try:
226                result = future.result()
227                results.append(result)
228            except Exception as e:
229                print(f"Simulation failed: {e}")
230                results.append(None)
231
232        return results
233
234
235def run_parallel_simulations(
236    simulation_configs: List[dict],
237    max_workers: Optional[int] = None
238) -> List[ResultContainer]:
239    """Run multiple simulations in parallel.
240
241    Parameters
242    ----------
243    simulation_configs : list
244        List of simulation configuration dictionaries
245    max_workers : int, optional
246        Maximum number of worker threads
247
248    Returns
249    -------
250    list
251        List of simulation results
252    """
253    def run_single_config(config):
254        from ..core.simulation_context import SimulationContext
255
256        # Create context and orchestrator for this configuration
257        context = SimulationContext(config.get('config_path', 'config.yaml'))
258        orchestrator = SequentialOrchestrator(context)
259
260        return orchestrator.execute(
261            config['initial_state'],
262            config['control_inputs'],
263            config['dt'],
264            config['horizon'],
265            **config.get('kwargs', {})
266        )
267
268    with WorkerPool(max_workers) as pool:
269        results = pool.map_simulations(run_single_config,
270                                     [(config,) for config in simulation_configs])
271
272    return results

ClassesÂ¶

ParallelOrchestratorÂ¶

Inherits from: BaseOrchestrator

Parallel simulation orchestrator for multi-threaded execution.

This orchestrator executes multiple simulations in parallel using a thread pool, providing performance improvements for independent simulation runs such as Monte Carlo analysis.

Source CodeÂ¶

  1class ParallelOrchestrator(BaseOrchestrator):
  2    """Parallel simulation orchestrator for multi-threaded execution.
  3
  4    This orchestrator executes multiple simulations in parallel using
  5    a thread pool, providing performance improvements for independent
  6    simulation runs such as Monte Carlo analysis.
  7    """
  8
  9    def __init__(self, context, max_workers: Optional[int] = None):
 10        """Initialize parallel orchestrator.
 11
 12        Parameters
 13        ----------
 14        context : SimulationContext
 15            Simulation context
 16        max_workers : int, optional
 17            Maximum number of worker threads (default: CPU count)
 18        """
 19        super().__init__(context)
 20        self.max_workers = max_workers
 21
 22    def execute(self,
 23               initial_state: np.ndarray,
 24               control_inputs: np.ndarray,
 25               dt: float,
 26               horizon: int,
 27               **kwargs) -> ResultContainer:
 28        """Execute parallel simulation.
 29
 30        Parameters
 31        ----------
 32        initial_state : np.ndarray
 33            Initial state(s) - shape (state_dim,) or (batch_size, state_dim)
 34        control_inputs : np.ndarray
 35            Control input sequence(s)
 36        dt : float
 37            Time step
 38        horizon : int
 39            Simulation horizon
 40        **kwargs
 41            Additional options
 42
 43        Returns
 44        -------
 45        ResultContainer
 46            Parallel simulation results
 47        """
 48        self._validate_simulation_inputs(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon)
 49
 50        start_time = time.perf_counter()
 51
 52        # Determine if this is a batch of simulations
 53        initial_state = np.atleast_2d(initial_state)
 54        batch_size = initial_state.shape[0]
 55
 56        if batch_size == 1:
 57            # Single simulation - use sequential orchestrator
 58            sequential = SequentialOrchestrator(self.context)
 59            result = sequential.execute(initial_state[0], control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)
 60        else:
 61            # Multiple simulations - execute in parallel
 62            result = self._execute_parallel_batch(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)
 63
 64        # Update statistics
 65        execution_time = time.perf_counter() - start_time
 66        total_steps = batch_size * horizon
 67        self._update_stats(total_steps, execution_time)
 68
 69        return result
 70
 71    def _execute_parallel_batch(self,
 72                               initial_states: np.ndarray,
 73                               control_inputs: np.ndarray,
 74                               dt: float,
 75                               horizon: int,
 76                               **kwargs) -> ResultContainer:
 77        """Execute batch simulations in parallel."""
 78        batch_size = initial_states.shape[0]
 79
 80        # Prepare individual simulation parameters
 81        simulation_params = []
 82        for i in range(batch_size):
 83            initial_state = initial_states[i]
 84
 85            # Extract control inputs for this simulation
 86            if control_inputs.ndim == 1:
 87                # Single control sequence for all
 88                controls = control_inputs
 89            elif control_inputs.ndim == 2:
 90                if control_inputs.shape[0] == batch_size:
 91                    # Batch of control sequences
 92                    controls = control_inputs[i]
 93                else:
 94                    # Single control sequence with multiple inputs per step
 95                    controls = control_inputs
 96            elif control_inputs.ndim == 3:
 97                # Batch of multi-input control sequences
 98                controls = control_inputs[i]
 99            else:
100                controls = control_inputs
101
102            simulation_params.append((initial_state, controls, dt, horizon, kwargs.copy()))
103
104        # Execute simulations in parallel
105        results = []
106        with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=self.max_workers) as executor:
107            # Submit all simulations
108            future_to_index = {
109                executor.submit(self._run_single_simulation, *params): i
110                for i, params in enumerate(simulation_params)
111            }
112
113            # Collect results as they complete
114            for future in as_completed(future_to_index):
115                index = future_to_index[future]
116                try:
117                    result = future.result()
118                    results.append((index, result))
119                except Exception as e:
120                    # Handle failed simulation
121                    print(f"Simulation {index} failed: {e}")
122                    results.append((index, None))
123
124        # Sort results by original index
125        results.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
126
127        # Combine into batch result container
128        batch_result = BatchResultContainer()
129        for index, result in results:
130            if result is not None:
131                states = result.get_states()
132                times = result.get_times()
133                controls = getattr(result, 'controls', None)
134
135                batch_result.add_trajectory(states, times,
136                                          controls=controls, batch_index=index)
137
138        return batch_result
139
140    def _run_single_simulation(self,
141                             initial_state: np.ndarray,
142                             control_inputs: np.ndarray,
143                             dt: float,
144                             horizon: int,
145                             kwargs: dict) -> ResultContainer:
146        """Run a single simulation using sequential orchestrator.
147
148        This method creates a new sequential orchestrator for each worker
149        to avoid thread safety issues.
150        """
151        # Create a new context for this thread
152        context = type(self.context)(self.context.config.model_dump_json())
153        sequential = SequentialOrchestrator(context)
154
155        return sequential.execute(initial_state, control_inputs, dt, horizon, **kwargs)

WorkerPoolÂ¶

Reusable worker pool for parallel simulations.

Source CodeÂ¶

 1class WorkerPool:
 2    """Reusable worker pool for parallel simulations."""
 3
 4    def __init__(self, max_workers: Optional[int] = None):
 5        """Initialize worker pool.
 6
 7        Parameters
 8        ----------
 9        max_workers : int, optional
10            Maximum number of worker threads
11        """
12        self.max_workers = max_workers
13        self.executor = None
14
15    def __enter__(self):
16        """Enter context manager."""
17        self.executor = ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=self.max_workers)
18        return self
19
20    def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb):
21        """Exit context manager."""
22        if self.executor:
23            self.executor.shutdown(wait=True)
24
25    def map_simulations(self,
26                       simulation_fn: Callable,
27                       parameters: List[Any]) -> List[Any]:
28        """Map simulation function over parameter list.
29
30        Parameters
31        ----------
32        simulation_fn : callable
33            Simulation function to execute
34        parameters : list
35            List of parameter tuples for each simulation
36
37        Returns
38        -------
39        list
40            List of simulation results
41        """
42        if self.executor is None:
43            raise RuntimeError("Worker pool not initialized. Use as context manager.")
44
45        futures = [self.executor.submit(simulation_fn, *params) for params in parameters]
46        results = []
47
48        for future in as_completed(futures):
49            try:
50                result = future.result()
51                results.append(result)
52            except Exception as e:
53                print(f"Simulation failed: {e}")
54                results.append(None)
55
56        return results

FunctionsÂ¶

run_parallel_simulations(simulation_configs, max_workers)Â¶

Run multiple simulations in parallel.

ParametersÂ¶

simulation_configs : list List of simulation configuration dictionaries max_workers : int, optional Maximum number of worker threads

ReturnsÂ¶

list List of simulation results

Source CodeÂ¶

 1def run_parallel_simulations(
 2    simulation_configs: List[dict],
 3    max_workers: Optional[int] = None
 4) -> List[ResultContainer]:
 5    """Run multiple simulations in parallel.
 6
 7    Parameters
 8    ----------
 9    simulation_configs : list
10        List of simulation configuration dictionaries
11    max_workers : int, optional
12        Maximum number of worker threads
13
14    Returns
15    -------
16    list
17        List of simulation results
18    """
19    def run_single_config(config):
20        from ..core.simulation_context import SimulationContext
21
22        # Create context and orchestrator for this configuration
23        context = SimulationContext(config.get('config_path', 'config.yaml'))
24        orchestrator = SequentialOrchestrator(context)
25
26        return orchestrator.execute(
27            config['initial_state'],
28            config['control_inputs'],
29            config['dt'],
30            config['horizon'],
31            **config.get('kwargs', {})
32        )
33
34    with WorkerPool(max_workers) as pool:
35        results = pool.map_simulations(run_single_config,
36                                     [(config,) for config in simulation_configs])
37
38    return results
